I'm sure it must be. I know that I was testing some actions and I
needed to create an ActionMapping object from scratch. I suspect that
by careful observation of the API of a DynaActionForm, you should be
able to build one yourself.

To get a good understanding of what went into an ActionMapping, I used
the debugger in my IDE and set a breakpoint in my action and drilled
down into the mapping. You could do the same with the DynaActionForm.

Simon

On 8/9/06, Chuck <nessies2003@...> wrote:
> Hello,
> I'm currently writing tests for my web-applicaiton using JUnit and I
> came across a method I need to test that takes a DynaActionForm as a
> parameter.  Problem is, I can't get ahold of the form with the beans
> it needs inside of the method, from my JUnit test.  Is there a way to
> initialize a new ActionForm object from scratch using either an action
> path as a string or a form-bean name?
>
> -Chuck
